[[Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford]] }} '''Ann Noreen Widdecombe''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|PC|size=100%|DSG}} (born 4 October 1947) is a British former politician. She was a [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Privy Councillor]] and was the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] Member of Parliament for [[Maidstone (UK Parliament constituency)|Maidstone]] from 1987-1997 and for [[Maidstone and The Weald (UK Parliament constituency)|Maidstone and The Weald]] from 1997-2010. She was a [[social conservative]], a member of the [[Conservative Christian Fellowship]] and retired from politics at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]]. Since 2002, she has also made numerous television and radio appearances, including as a television presenter. She is a convert from [[Anglicanism]] to [[Roman Catholicism]]. As an MP, Widdecombe was known for opposing the legality of abortion, her opposition to various issues of [[LGBT]] rights such as an equal [[age of consent]] and the repeal of [[Section 28]], her support for the re-introduction of the [[death penalty]], the retention of blasphemy laws and her opposition to [[fox hunting]]. ==Early life== Born in [[Bath, Somerset]], Widdecombe is the daughter of Rita Noreen (née Plummer; 1911-2007) and [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] civil servant James Murray Widdecombe. Widdecombe's maternal grandfather, James Henry Plummer, was born to an [[Irish Catholic]] family of English descent in [[Crosshaven]], [[County Cork]] in 1874. She attended the Royal Naval School in [[Singapore]],[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7032992.stm Ann Widdecombe set to stand down]; ''[[BBC News]]'', 7 October 2007 and La Sainte Union [[Convent]] School in Bath.{{cite web|url=http://www.annwiddecombe.com/text.aspx?id=52|title=About Ann|publisher=annwiddecombe.com|accessdate=8 October 2009}} She then read [[Latin]] at the [[University of Birmingham]] and later attended [[Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford]], to read [[Philosophy, Politics and Economics]] (PPE).{{cite web | url=http://www.lmh.ox.ac.uk/Alumni/Prominent-alumni.aspx | title=LMH, Oxford - Prominent Alumni|accessdate=20 May 2015}} While studying at Oxford, she lived next door to [[Mary Archer]], [[Edwina Currie]], and [[Gyles Brandreth]]'s wife Michèle Brown.{{cite news|title=Have I Got News For You, Series 25 Episode 6 with Hugh Dennis, Gyles Brandreth & Martin Freeman|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MTZWT0OMpy0}} She worked for [[Unilever]] (1973–75) and then as an administrator at the [[University of London]] (1975–87) before entering Parliament. ===Councillor=== From 1976 to 1978, Widdecombe was a [[councillor]] on [[Runnymede (borough)|Runnymede District]] Council in Surrey.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2003/nov/03/uk.conservatives|title=Seeing something of the light at the end of the tunnel|date=3 November 2003|work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=6 December 2008 | first=Jackie | last=Ashley}} She contested the seat of [[Burnley (UK Parliament constituency)|Burnley]] in Lancashire in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|1979 general election]] and then, against [[David Owen]], the [[Plymouth Devonport (UK Parliament constituency)|Plymouth Devonport]] seat in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|1983 general election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.psr.keele.ac.uk/area/uk/ge79/i04.htm|title=UK General Election results May 1979|date=3 May 1979|work=Political Science Resources|publisher=Richard Kimber|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060925040210/http://www.psr.keele.ac.uk/area/uk/ge79/i04.htm|archivedate=25 September 2006|accessdate=16 November 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.psr.keele.ac.uk/area/uk/ge83/i16.htm|title=UK General Election results June 1983|date=9 June 1983|work=Political Science Resources|publisher=Richard Kimber|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080320065802/http://www.psr.keele.ac.uk/area/uk/ge83/i16.htm|archivedate=20 March 2008|accessdate=16 November 2008}} ==Member of Parliament== She was first elected to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1987|1987 general election]] as member for the constituency of [[Maidstone (UK Parliament constituency)|Maidstone]] (which became [[Maidstone and The Weald (UK Parliament constituency)|Maidstone and The Weald]] in 1997).[http://ukpollingreport.co.uk/guide/seat-profiles/maidstoneandtheweald Maidstone and The Weald], UKPollingReport ===Political views=== As an MP, Widdecombe expressed conservative views, including opposition to abortion; it was understood during her time in frontline politics that she would not become [[Secretary of State for Health|Health Secretary]] as long as this involved responsibility for abortions. Although a committed Christian, she has characterised the issue as one of life and death on which her view had been the same when she was agnostic{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/280692.stm|work=BBC News | title=Ann Widdecombe answers your questions | date=16 February 1999 | accessdate=30 April 2010}} and was a member of the [[Society for the Protection of Unborn Children]] while studying at Oxford.{{cite news |last1=Roth |first1=Andrew |title=Ann Widdecombe |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2001/mar/20/profiles.parliament16 |accessdate=31 August 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=20 March 2001}} Along with [[John Gummer]] MP, she converted from the [[Church of England]] to the Catholic Church following the decision of the Church of England on the [[Ordination of women]] as priests.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/112152.stm |work=BBC News | title=Widdecombe rejects abortion role | date=13 June 1998 | accessdate=25 April 2010}} In her speech at the 2000 Conservative conference, she called for a [[zero tolerance]] policy of prosecution, with the punishment of £100 fines for users of [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]]. This was well received by rank-and-file Conservative delegates.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2000/oct/06/drugsandalcohol.conservatives2000|title=Widdecombe fights back firm|last=Watt|first=Nicholas|date=6 October 2000|work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=22 August 2009 }} She is a committed animal lover and one of the few Conservative MPs to have consistently voted for the ban on [[fox hunting]].[http://www.publicwhip.org.uk/mp.php?mpid=1701&dmp=1050 "Ann Widdecombe compared to 'Fox hunting – Ban'"], [[Public Whip]]. Retrieved on 21 March 2009. Widdecombe was among more than 20 high-profile people who signed a letter to Members of Parliament in 2015 to oppose David Cameron's plan to amend the [[Hunting Act 2004]].{{cite news|url=http://news.stv.tv/scotland-decides/news/1324609-snp-to-vote-against-tories-on-fox-hunting-ban-in-england-and-wales/ |title=SNP to vote against Tories on fox hunting ban in England and Wales |work=STV |date=13 July 2015 |accessdate=17 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150715203740/http://news.stv.tv/scotland-decides/news/1324609-snp-to-vote-against-tories-on-fox-hunting-ban-in-england-and-wales/ |archivedate=15 July 2015 }} She has expressed a variety of views on scientific issues such as [[climate change]] but has been opposed to legislation reducing emissions. Her views on the subject appear to have hardened over time. In 2007, she wrote that she did not want to belittle the issue but was sceptical of the claims that specific actions would prevent catastrophe,{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/2489/Switching-lightbulbs-won-t-save-the-world |title=Switching Lightbulbs won't change the world |publisher=Express.co.uk |date=21 March 2007 |accessdate=26 August 2011}} then in 2008 that her doubts had been "crystalised" by Nigel Lawson's book ''[[An Appeal to Reason]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/ourcomments/view/48856 |title=Yes, I am a heretic on global warming |publisher=Express.co.uk |date=18 June 2008 |accessdate=26 August 2011}} before stating in 2009 that "There is no climate change, hasn’t anybody looked out of their window recently?"{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/79580/Now-the-EU-wants-to-ban-your-plasma-television |title=Article including refutation of any global warming |publisher=Express.co.uk |date=12 January 2009 |accessdate=26 August 2011}} She was one of the five MPs who voted against the [[Climate Change Act 2008]].{{cite web |url=http://www.publicwhip.org.uk/division.php?date=2008-10-28&number=298 |title=Climate Change Bill — Third Reading (and other amendments) |date=28 October 2008 |publisher=The Public Whip |accessdate=31 October 2014 }} In 2011 she expressed the view that "climate change money should go to armed services".{{cite web | url=http://www.express.co.uk/ourcomments/view/262765 | title=Climate change money should go to armed services |publisher=[[Daily Express]] |year=2011 |accessdate=9 October 2012}} The previous year, she voted to support a parliamentary motion supporting [[homeopathy]], criticising the Science and Technology Committee's Report on the subject.{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/edm/2009-10/908 |title=UK Parliament Early day motion 908 |publisher=Parliament UK |date=23 February 2010 |accessdate=10 August 2015}} Over the years, Widdecombe has expressed her support for a reintroduction of the death penalty, which was abolished in the UK in 1965. She notably spoke of her support for its reintroduction for the worst cases of murder in the aftermath of the murder of two 10-year-old girls from [[Soham]], Cambridgeshire, in August 2002, in the [[Soham murders]]. She supported the argument that the death penalty would have deterrent value, as within five years of its abolition the national murder rate had more than doubled.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/2204738.stm |title=UK | Politics | Death penalty call renewed |publisher=BBC News |date=21 August 2002 |accessdate=26 August 2011}} ====LGBT rights==== Although she supported the UK's [[Sexual Offences Act 1967|partial decriminalisation of homosexuality in 1967]], Widdecombe has consistently opposed [[LGBT]] rights while in Parliament, saying in 1999 that "I do not think that [homosexuality] can be promoted as an equally valid lifestyle to [heterosexual] marriage, but I would say the same about irregular heterosexual arrangements." She has consistently argued against an equal [[age of consent]] for same-sex relationships – first in 1994 (voting against the [[Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994|1994 Act]], which would have [[Age of consent reform in the United Kingdom|reduced the age of consent]] for some male-male sexual activity in the UK from 21 to 18), and secondly in 1998 (arguing against a further reduction from 18 to 16, which later occurred [[Sexual Offences (Amendment) Act 2000|in 2000]]);{{cite journal |last1=Roth |first1=Andrew |authorlink1=Andrew Roth |title=Ann (Noreen) WIDDECOMBE |journal=Parliamentary Profile Services Ltd |page=4 |url=http://internetserver.bishopsgate.org.uk/files/Parliamentary%20Profiles%20Archive/S-Z/WIDDECOMBE,%20Anne/WIDDECOMBE,%20Anne.pdf |accessdate=7 September 2018 |format=[[PDF]]}}{{cite news |last1=Widdecombe |first1=Ann |title=Protect your sons from legal gay sex at 16 |work=[[The Mail on Sunday]] |date=24 May 1998 |page=34}} On the latter point, she wrote in ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]'' that "one of the sundry horrors for which this Government is likely to be remembered will be that it gave its [[wikt:imprimatur|imprimatur]] to sodomy at 16", adding that if the age of consent was equalised, "there will be no protection for the vulnerable and confused against the predatory attentions of older men". She later said in 2000: "I do not believe that issues of equality should override the imperatives of protecting the young."{{cite news | url= https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2000/feb/11/uk.politicalnews1 | title= Commons approves bill to lower gay age of consent | work=The Guardian | location=London | date=11 February 2000 | accessdate=2 June 2015}} In 2003, Widdecombe proposed an amendment opposing repeal of [[Section 28]] of the [[Local Government Act 1988|Local Government Act]], which banned the "[[promotion of homosexuality]]" by local governments. Out of the 17 parliamentary votes considered by the [[Public Whip]] website to concern equal rights for homosexuals, Widdecombe took the opposing position in 15 cases, not being present at the other two votes.[http://www.publicwhip.org.uk/mp.php?mpid=1701&dmp=826 "Ann Widdecombe compared to 'Homosexuality – Equal rights'"], [[Public Whip]]. Retrieved on 24 June 2009. Widdecombe has also expressed her opposition to [[Same-sex marriage in the United Kingdom|same-sex marriage]], introduced by [[David Cameron]]'s government in 2014, again claiming that "the state must have a preferred model" and "a union that is generally open to procreation".{{cite news | url= https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2013/jun/06/ann-widdecombe-david-cameron-listen-people | title= Ann Widdecombe: 'I wish David Cameron would listen to people' | work=The Guardian | location=London | first=Stephen | last=Moss | date=6 June 2013 | accessdate=8 Feb 2014}} In 2012, Widdecombe voiced support in the ''[[Daily Express]]'' for the discredited and psychologically damaging practise of [[conversion therapy]], which claims to change the orientation of gay men and women.{{cite web|last1=Widdecombe|first1=Ann|title=Helping those who aren’t glad to be gay|url=https://www.express.co.uk/comment/columnists/ann-widdecombe/299271/Helping-those-who-aren-t-glad-to-be-gay|website=The Daily Express|accessdate=2 January 2018|language=en|date=1 February 2012}}{{cite web|last1=Simons|first1=Ned|title=Ann Widdecombe Defends Gay Conversion Therapy|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/02/02/anne-widdecome-defends-gay-conversion-therapy_n_1249697.html|website=The Huffington Post|accessdate=2 January 2018|date=2 February 2012}} ===In government=== Widdecombe joined [[John Major]]'s government as [[Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State]] for Social Security in 1990. In 1993, she was moved to the [[Department of Employment]], and she was promoted to [[Minister of State]] the following year. In 1995, she joined the [[Home Office]] as Minister of State for Prisons and visited every prison in the UK.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/talking_politics/104160.stm|title=Ann Widdecombe – political sketch |publisher=BBC Online |accessdate=17 June 2009 |date=2 June 1998 |location=London}} ===Shadow Cabinet=== After the Conservative landslide defeat at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]], she served as [[Shadow Secretary of State for Health|Shadow Health Secretary]] between 1998-1999 and later as [[Shadow Home Secretary]] between 1999-2001 under the leadership of [[William Hague]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/person/5516/ann-widdecombe|title=Ann Widdecombe: Electoral history and profile|work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=22 August 2009 }} ===Leadership contest and backbenches=== [[File:Ann Widdecombe.jpg|upright|thumb|Widdecombe in 2006]] During the [[Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2001|2001 Conservative leadership election]], she could not find sufficient support amongst Conservative MPs for her leadership candidacy. She first supported [[Michael Ancram]], who was eliminated in the first round, and then [[Kenneth Clarke]], who lost in the final round. She afterwards declined to serve in [[Shadow Cabinet of Iain Duncan Smith|Iain Duncan Smith's Shadow Cabinet]] (although she indicated on the television programme ''[[When Louis Met...]]'', prior to the leadership contest, that she wished to retire to the [[backbenches]] anyway). In the [[Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2005|2005 leadership election]], she initially supported Kenneth Clarke again. Once he was eliminated, she turned support towards [[Liam Fox]]. Following Fox's subsequent elimination, she took time to reflect before finally declaring for [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]]. She expressed reservations over the eventual winner [[David Cameron]], feeling that he did not, like the other candidates, have a proven track record, and she was later a leading figure in The matter was resolved when the company reversed the suspension.{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/article.html?in_article_id=21286&in_page_id=34|title=Widdecombe pledges to boycott BA|date=15 October 2006|publisher=Metro|accessdate=22 August 2009}} In 2010, Widdecombe turned down an offer to be Britain's next ambassador to the [[Holy See]], being prevented from accepting by suffering a [[detached retina]].{{cite web|last=Crampton|first=Caroline|title=Ann Widdecombe rules out Vatican appointment|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/the-staggers/2010/07/detached-retina-post-vatican|publisher=The New Statesman|accessdate=16 December 2012}} She was made a Dame of the [[Order of St. Gregory the Great]] by [[Pope Benedict XVI]] for services to politics and public life on 31 January 2013.{{cite news |url=http://www.indcatholicnews.com/news.php?viewStory=21860 |title=Ann Widdecombe awarded papal honour |publisher=Independent Catholic News |date=31 January 2013 |accessdate=2 February 2013}} ==Controversies== In 1990, following the assassination of the Conservative politician [[Ian Gow]] by the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] (IRA), the [[Eastbourne by-election, 1990|Eastbourne by-election]] for his seat in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] was won by the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] [[David Bellotti]]. Upon the announcement, Widdecombe told the voters that the IRA would be "toasting their success". In 1996, Widdecombe, as prisons minister, defended the Government's policy to [[Use of restraints on pregnant women|shackle pregnant prisoners]] with handcuffs and chains when in hospital receiving ante-natal care. Widdecombe told the Commons the restrictions were needed to prevent prisoners from escaping. "Some MPs may like to think that a pregnant woman would not or could not escape. Unfortunately this is not true. The fact is that hospitals are not secure places in which to keep prisoners, and since 1990, 20 women have escaped from hospitals". [[Jack Straw]], Labour's Home Affairs spokesman at the time, said it was "degrading and unnecessary" for a woman to be shackled at any stage.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/chaining-women-backed-1323238.html|title=Chaining women backed|work=The Independent |location=London |date=10 January 1996 |accessdate=20 October 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101012143641/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/chaining-women-backed-1323238.html| archivedate= 12 October 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2000/mar/18/fiction1|title=Hague's head girl|work=The Guardian |location=London |date=18 March 2000|accessdate=20 October 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100916011112/http://www.guardian.co.uk/books/2000/mar/18/fiction1| archivedate= 16 September 2010 | deadurl= no}} In 1997, during the Conservative leadership election of [[William Hague]], Widdecombe spoke out against [[Michael Howard]], under whom she had served when he was Home Secretary. She remarked in the House of Commons that there is "something of the night" about him.{{cite news|last1=Sengupta|first1=Kim|last2=Abrams|first2=Fran|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/widdecombe-goes-for-the-jugular-1261224.html?amp|title=Widdecombe goes for the jugular|work=The Independent|date=12 May 1997|accessdate=3 April 2017}} The remark was considered to be [[antisemitic]] by some{{cite book|author=Frederic Raphael|title=Anti-Semitism: (Provocations)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n_RBCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT68|date=25 August 2015|publisher=Biteback Publishing|isbn=978-1-84954-962-2|page=68}} and was damaging to Howard, who came last in the first round, an opinion both former ministers share.{{cite news|last=Crick|first=Michael|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/mission-accomplished-how-howard-was-knifed-757lktbmgdt|title=‘Mission accomplished’: how Howard was knifed|work=The Times|date=30 March 2005|accessdate=3 April 2017}} {{subscription required}} Extract from Crick's book ''In search of Michael Howard''.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8435904.stm|title=Ann Widdecombe 'tested out' Howard quip|publisher=BBC News|date=31 December 2009|accessdate=3 April 2017}} Howard still became party leader in 2003, and Widdecombe then stated, "I explained fully what my objections were in 1997 and I do not retract anything I said then. But ... we have to look to the future and not the past."{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/webchats/webchat.html?in_page_id=1868&in_article_id=343672 |title=Live chat with Tory Ann Widdecombe at |work=Daily Mail |location=UK |date=10 October 2002 |accessdate=26 August 2011}} In 2001, when [[Michael Portillo]] was running for leader of the Conservative Party, Widdecombe described him and his allies as "[[wikt:backbiter|backbiters]]" due to his alleged destabilising influence under Hague.{{cite book|author=Timothy Heppell|title=Choosing the Tory Leader: Conservative Party Leadership Elections from Heath to Cameron|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4G0AAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA143|date=28 November 2007|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-0-85771-134-2|page=143}} She went on to say that, should he be appointed leader, she would never give him her allegiance. This was amidst a [[homophobic]] campaign led by socially conservative critics of Portillo. ==Media work and appearances== [[File:Any Questions, Nexus Methodist Church, Bath.jpg|thumb|Widdecombe in an ''[[Any Questions?]]'' broadcast in 2016 at the Nexus Methodist Church, Bath]] In 2002, she took part in the ITV programme ''[[Celebrity Fit Club (UK TV series)|Celebrity Fit Club]]''. Also in 2002 she took part in a [[Louis Theroux]] television documentary, depicting her life, both in and out of politics.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/ann-widdecombe-the-truth-about-me-and-louis-theroux-659429.html|title=Ann Widdecombe: The truth about me and Louis Theroux|work=The Independent |location=London |date=5 March 2002|accessdate=11 June 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100517063321/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/ann-widdecombe-the-truth-about-me-and-louis-theroux-659429.html| archivedate= 17 May 2010 | deadurl= no}} In March 2004 she briefly became ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper's [[agony aunt]], introduced with an [[Emma Brockes]] interview. In 2005 [[BBC Two]] showed six episodes of ''The Widdecombe Project'', an agony aunt television programme. In 2005, she appeared in a new series of ''Celebrity Fit Club'', but this time as a panel member dispensing wisdom and advice to the celebrities taking part.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/3558378.stm | title=MP Widdecombe is BBC agony aunt |publisher=BBC |accessdate=21 November 2010 | date=12 August 2004}} Also in 2005, she presented the show ''Ann Widdecombe to the Rescue'' in which she acted as an agony aunt, dispensing no-nonsense advice to disputing families, couples, and others across the UK.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/ann-widdecombe-mp--an-unlikely-agony-aunt-754932.html |title=Ann Widdecombe MP: an unlikely agony aunt |date=28 June 2005 |work=The Independent |location=London |accessdate=22 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kNM3gKPs?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/ann-widdecombe-mp--an-unlikely-agony-aunt-754932.html |archivedate=8 October 2009 |df=dmy }} In 2005, she also appeared in a discussion programme on [[Channel 5 (UK)|Five]] to discuss who had been England's greatest monarch since the [[Norman Conquest]]; her choice of monarch was [[Charles II of England|Charles II]].{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200407120003 |title=Diary – Jenni Bond |last=Bond |first=Jenni |date=12 July 2004 |work=New Statesman |location=UK |accessdate=22 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607074724/http://www.newstatesman.com/200407120003 |archivedate=7 June 2011 }} She was the guest host of news quiz ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'' twice, in 2006 and 2007. Following her second appearance, Widdecombe vowed she would never appear on the show again because of comments made by panellist [[Jimmy Carr]]. She wrote, "His idea of wit is a barrage of filth and the sort of humour most men grow out of in their teens.... [T]here's no amount of money for which I would go through those two recording hours again. At one stage I nearly walked out."Ann Widdecombe in the ''Daily Express'', as quoted by {{cite news|author1=Media Monkey|title=Widdecombe disgusted by Carr's 'filth'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/mediamonkeyblog/2007/nov/28/widdecombedisgustedbycarrs|accessdate=18 February 2018|work=The Guardian|date=28 November 2007}} She did, however, stand by her appraisal of regular panellists [[Ian Hislop]] and [[Paul Merton]], whom she has called "the fastest wits in showbusiness". Merton later revealed that he thought Widdecombe had been "the worst ever presenter" of the show, particularly on her second appearance where Merton claimed she "thought she was [[Victoria Wood]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2018/04/05/anti-lgbt-politician-ann-widdecombe-was-the-worst-have-i-got-news-for-you-presenter-ever/|title=Anti-LGBT politician Ann Widdecombe was the ‘worst Have I Got News For You presenter ever’ |last=Butterworth |first=Benjamin |date=5 April 2018 |work=Pink News|location=UK |accessdate=6 April 2018}} In 2007 she awarded the ''[[University Challenge]]'' trophy to the winners.{{cite web|url=http://www.ukgameshows.com/ukgs/University_Challenge|title=University Challenge|publisher=UK Game Shows.com|accessdate=22 August 2009}} In the same year, she was cast as herself in "[[The Sound of Drums (Doctor Who)|The Sound of Drums]]", the 12th episode of the third series of the science-fiction drama ''[[Doctor Who]]'' supporting [[Mr Saxon]], the alias of [[Master (Doctor Who)|the Master]].{{cite web|author=Peter Ware|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/episodes/2007/facts/fact_312.shtml|title=Doctor Who – Fact File – "The Sound of Drums"|work=Doctor Who: the official site|publisher=BBC |accessdate=30 November 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071017034012/http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/episodes/2007/facts/fact_312.shtml| archivedate= 17 October 2007 | deadurl= no}} Since 2007 Widdecombe has fronted a television [[Television season|series]] called ''Ann Widdecombe Versus'', on [[ITV1]], in which she speaks to various people about things related to her as an [[Member of Parliament|MP]], with an emphasis on confronting those responsible for problems she wished to tackle. On 15 August 2007 she talked about prostitution, the next week about [[Social welfare provision|benefits]] and the week after that about [[truancy]]. A fourth episode was screened on 18 September 2008 in which she travelled around London and [[Birmingham]] talking to girl gangs.{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article4781758.ece | title= Ann Widdecombe Versus Girl Gangs; No Heroics; Hollyoaks at timesonline.co.uk |accessdate=1 September 2011 | location=London |work=The Times |date=19 September 2008 |first1=Philippe |last1=Naughton |first2=Miles |last2=Costello}} In 2009, Widdecombe appeared with Archbishop [[John Onaiyekan]] in an "[[Intelligence Squared]]" debate in which they defended the motion that the Catholic Church was a force for good. Arguing against the motion were [[Stephen Fry]] and [[Christopher Hitchens]], who won the debate overall.{{Cite news|url=http://archive.catholicherald.co.uk/article/23rd-october-2009/1/atheist-duo-convince-crowd-that-the-church-is-not- |title=Atheist duo convince crowd that the Church is not a force for good |author=Ed West |work=The Catholic Herald |accessdate=18 February 2012 |location=London |date=23 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120626053333/http://archive.catholicherald.co.uk/article/23rd-october-2009/1/atheist-duo-convince-crowd-that-the-church-is-not- |archivedate=26 June 2012 }} In October 2010, she appeared on [[BBC One]]'s ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'', partnered by [[Anton du Beke]], winning the support of some viewers despite low marks from the judges.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b00v7qxs/Strictly_Come_Dancing_Series_8_Week_1_Show_2/ |title=Strictly Come Dancing at |publisher=BBC |date=2 October 2010 |accessdate=26 August 2011}}{{cite news|last=Grice |first=Elizabeth |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/strictly-come-dancing/8076273/Interview-with-Ann-Widdecombe.html |title=Interview with Ann Widdecombe at www.telegraph.co.uk |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |accessdate=26 August 2011 |date=21 October 2010}} After nine weeks of routines strongly flavoured by comedy the couple had received enough support in the public vote to stay in the contest. Widdecombe was eliminated from the competition on Sunday 5 December after the public vote had been combined with the judges' score; she was with [[Scott Maslen]] of ''EastEnders'' in the bottom two. In 2012, Widdecombe hosted a new quiz show for the [[Sky Atlantic]] channel, called ''[[Cleverdicks]]''. The show ran for one series with 30 one-hour episodes. It featured four contestants, usually high quality members of the UK national quiz circuit and ended with a money round for the winner of each show.{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/277070/Ann-Widdecombe-to-host-new-TV-quiz-show|title=Ann Widdecombe to host new TV quiz show|author=|date=|work=Express.co.uk}} In April 2012 Widdecombe presented an hour-long documentary for [[BBC Radio 5 Live]], ''Drunk Again: Ann Widdecombe Investigates'', looking at how the British attitude to [[alcohol consumption]] has changed over the last few years.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01ghshj |title=Drunk Again: Anne Widdecombe Investigates |publisher=BBC |date=23 April 2012 |accessdate=23 April 2012}}{{cite news|last1=Sawyer|first1=Miranda|title=Rewind radio: Drunk Again: Ann Widdecombe Investigates; Sunday Feature: AL Kennedy's Art of Madness; The Radio Ballads: Never Again – A Lament for the Titanic – review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2012/apr/29/drunk-again-ann-widdecombe-review|accessdate=5 February 2018|work=The Guardian|date=28 April 2012|language=en}} It was revealed in October 2012, that the year's [[Children in Need]]'s appeal night would feature a ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'' special with former show favourites [[Russell Grant]] and Widdecombe.{{cite web |first=Alex |last=Fletcher |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/s104/strictly-come-dancing/news/a434358/russell-grant-widdecombe-return-to-strictly-for-children-in-need.html |title=Russell Grant, Widdecombe return to 'Strictly' for Children in Need |publisher=digitalspy.co.uk |date=30 October 2012 |accessdate=2 November 2012}} On 4 November 2012, Widdecombe guest-hosted one episode of BBC's ''[[Songs of Praise]]'' programme about singleness.{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/Ann-s-happy-Strictly-singleton/story-17236462-detail/story.html |title=Ann's happy to be Strictly a singleton |publisher=thisisstaffordshire.co.uk|date=5 November 2012 |accessdate=5 November 2012}} In October 2014, she appeared in the BBC series ''[[Antiques Road Trip|Celebrity Antiques Road Trip]]'', partnered with expert [[Mark Stacey]], where the pair beat the rival team of [[Craig Revel Horwood]] and Catherine Southon.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b016nbj8|title=BBC Two - Celebrity Antiques Road Trip, Series 1, Episode 1|author=|date=|work=BBC}} Widdecombe took part in a television series ''[[24 Hours in the Past]]'', along with [[Colin Jackson]], [[Alistair McGowan]], [[Miquita Oliver]], [[Tyger Drew-Honey]] and [[Zoe Lucker]]. The four-part series was aired from 28 April–19 May 2015 on [[BBC One]]. She took part in an episode of ''[[Tipping Point: Lucky Stars]]'' in 2016. In 2017, Widdecombe took part in ITV's ''[[Sugar Free Farm]]''. In January 2018, Widdecombe was the first to enter the ''[[Celebrity Big Brother (UK TV series)|Celebrity Big Brother]]'' house to participate as a housemate in its [[Celebrity Big Brother 21 (UK)|twenty-first series]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-42552217|title=Who's in the new Celebrity Big Brother house?|date=2018|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-01-27}} A controversial figure in the house, she was criticised over her comments regarding the [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations|Harvey Weinstein controversy]]{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/celebrity-big-brother-2018-line-up-ann-widdecombe-harvey-weinstein-victim-blaming-a8141096.html|title=Ann Widdecombe accused of victim blaming after CBB Weinstein discussion|date=4 January 2018|publisher=|accessdate=10 January 2018}} as well as comments perceived to be anti-LGBT to her fellow housemates, most notably to drag queen [[Courtney Act]] (Shane Jenek).{{cite news|last1=Chakelian|first1=Anoosh|title=Ann Widdecombe isn’t a harmless comedy old lady – she’s a homophobe|url=https://www.newstatesman.com/culture/tv-radio/2018/01/Celebrity-Big-Brother-ann-widdecombe-isn-t-harmless-comedy-old-lady-she-s-homophobe|accessdate=2 February 2018|work=New Statesman|date=31 January 2018}}{{cite news|last1=Cumberbatch|first1=Aimée Grant|title=Celebrity Big Brother fans brand Ann Widdecombe a ‘homophobe’|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/stayingin/tvfilm/celebrity-big-brother-fans-brand-ann-widdecombe-a-homophobe-after-latest-controversial-remark-a3747436.html|accessdate=2 February 2018|work=Evening Standard|date=23 January 2018}} She finished the competition in second place as runner-up to Jenek, who became popular with viewers for challenging Widdecombe's comments.{{cite news|last1=Powell|first1=Emma|title=Courtney Act aka Shane Jenek beats Ann Widdecombe to win CBB|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/stayingin/tvfilm/celebrity-big-brother-2018-courtney-act-aka-shane-jenek-beats-ann-widdecombe-to-win-channel-5-a3757021.html|accessdate=16 February 2018|work=Evening Standard}} ==Stage acting career== Following her retirement, Widdecombe made her stage debut, on 9 December 2011, at the Orchard Theatre, [[Dartford]] in the Christmas pantomime ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]'', alongside ''Strictly Come Dancing'' judge [[Craig Revel Horwood]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-kent-12626500|title=Ann Widdecombe to star in panto in Dartford|author=|date=|work=BBC News}} In April 2012, she had a ten-minute non-singing cameo part in [[Gaetano Donizetti]]'s comic opera ''[[La Fille Du Regiment]]'', playing the Duchesse de Crackentorp.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17783927|title=Ann Widdecombe makes opera debut|author=|date=|work=BBC News}} Widdecombe reprised her pantomime performance, again with Revel Horwood, at the Swan Theatre, [[High Wycombe]] in December 2012.{{cite web|url=https://wycombeswan.co.uk/Online/default.asp?doWork::WScontent::loadArticle=Load&BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::article_id=C3E6222D-6C32-4FA6-816D-BC022B374015|title=HQ Theatres|author=|date=|work=wycombeswan.co.uk}} Widdecombe stepped in at short notice to play the [[Evil Queen]] in the [[pantomime]] ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]'' at [[Bridlington Spa]] in December 2016. She replaced [[Lorraine Chase]]; who had been injured in an accident two weeks before rehearsals were due to commence. This was Widdecombe's first appearance as a pantomime 'baddie'; a role she told the press she had always hoped for.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bridlingtonfreepress.co.uk/news/widdecombe-quick-steps-in-to-save-the-show-1-8247077|title=Widdecombe quick-steps in to save the show|website=www.bridlingtonfreepress.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-01-04}} In December 2017 Widdecombe played the [[List of consorts of rulers of China|Empress of China]] in the pantomime ''[[Aladdin]]'' at the Marina Theatre in [[Lowestoft]].{{cite web|url=http://www.marinatheatre.co.uk/production/marina-panto-2017-aladdin/|title=Marina Panto 2017: Aladdin - Marina Theatre|website=www.marinatheatre.co.uk}} The production was the theatre's most successful pantomime to date.{{cite web|url=http://www.lowestoftjournal.co.uk/news/aladdin-pantomime-success-ann-widdecombe-mark-read-marina-theatre-1-5343944|title=Record number attend annual pantomime featuring Ann Widdecombe and Mark Read|first=Thomas|last=Chapman|publisher=|accessdate=3 February 2018}} ==Honours== *Widdecombe was appointed an [[Honorary Fellow]] of [[Canterbury Christ Church University]] at a ceremony held at [[Canterbury Cathedral]] on 30 January 2009.{{cite web |title=Widdecombe, Holland and Underwood are appointed honorary fellows |publisher=[[Canterbury Christ Church University]] |date=3 February 2009 |url=http://www.canterbury.ac.uk/News/newsRelease.asp?newsPk=1301 |accessdate=19 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720143843/http://www.canterbury.ac.uk/News/newsRelease.asp?newsPk=1301 |archivedate=20 July 2011 }} *{{Flag|Holy See}}: Dame of the [[Order of St Gregory the Great]] (DSG) (2013) ==Selected publications== ===Fiction=== * 2000: ''The Clematis Tree''. London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson {{ISBN|0-297-64572-2}} * 2002: ''An Act of Treachery''. London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson {{ISBN|0-297-64573-0}} * 2005: ''Father Figure''. London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson {{ISBN|0-297-82962-9}} * 2005: ''An Act of Peace''. London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson {{ISBN|0-297-82958-0}} ===Non-fiction=== * 1999: ''Inspired and Outspoken: the collected speeches of Ann Widdecombe''; edited by John Simmons, with a biographical preface by Nick Kochan. London: Politico's Publishing {{ISBN|1-902301-22-6}} *2004: ''The Mass is a Mess'', with Martin Kochanski. London: Catholic Writers' Guild ==Further reading== * 2000: Kochan, Nicholas ''Ann Widdecombe: right from the beginning''. Alamgir I | image = File:Aurangzeb-portrait.jpg | caption = Emperor Aurangzeb seated on a throne in the darbar with a Hawk | succession = 6th [[Mughal emperors|Mughal Emperor]] | reign = 31 July 1658 – 3 March 1707 | coronation = 13 June 1659 at [[Shalimar Bagh, Delhi]] | predecessor = [[Shah Jahan]] | successor = [[Muhammad Azam Shah]] (titular)
